Appendix 1: Ward Attender Form Appendix 2: Transport Policy

A patient may present with an Ear, Nose and Throat (ENT) emergency at their general practitioner (GP) or at an accident and emergency department (A&E) which is most likely situated at their local (Spoke) hospital.
A small number of patients may make a self-referral. This will be by contacting at the ENT ward at the Hub hospital if they have had a procedure have been having problems since they were discharged.

The GP will contact the Junior Doctor (SHO) on call who is based at the Hub hospital (Broomfield) by telephone, normally via switchboard, and refer the patient with the ENT emergency. The SHO will ask for the patient to attend Mayflower ward (E322) for review. The GP will fax a letter of referral to the ward (currently fax number for E322 is 01245 516 302) or give it to the patient to bring with them.

The SHO must notify the ward nursing staff of any emergency patient who is expected. If the patient is a child the SHO must request that the child attends Moonbeam ward and the SHO must notify Moonbeam ward nursing staff of the expected emergency patient.
The patient may be sent in by ambulance if the GP has requested this or they may come by their own transport.

If a patient contacts ward E322 for advice the nursing staff will try to offer advice and reassurance over the telephone. The nursing staff should seek advice from the medical staff if required and ask the SHO on call to contact the patient by telephone or arrange for the patient to come up to the ward for review. The nursing staff should consult with the medical staff when they have advised a patient to attend the ward and notify them why the patient is attending and ask the doctor what time they are happy to see the patient.
If a patient presents at A&E they will be seen and assessed by the A&E team including the A&E medical staff.
Once the patient has been assessed one of the following outcomes will happen.
See and Treat

4.3.1 The patient is given the required treatment in A&E by the A&E doctor, advice and any required medication to take home will be given to the patient with instructions and the patient is discharged.

4.3.2 If a follow up appointment is needed the patient will be advised of any follow up appointments that may be required in the ENT clinic at their Spoke hospital. They will be told where and when to attend for their follow up appointment before they are discharged from A&E.
ENT opinion required

4.4.1 If an ENT opinion is required, the A&E doctor will contact the Junior Doctor (SHO) on call who is based at the Hub hospital (Broomfield) by telephone, via switchboard, and refer the patient with the ENT emergency.
4.4.2 The SHO will take a history from the A&E doctor and make a clinical decision on where the patient should be reviewed.

4.4.3 Once a history has been obtained, the SHO should ask the A&E doctor if the patient is in a stable enough condition to attend Ward E322 for review. If the patient is stable enough for transfer to ward E322 the A&E doctor should be asked to fax a copy of the A&E notes to the ward (currently fax number for E322 is 01245 516 302). They should also give a copy of the A&E notes to the patient to bring with them.

4.4.4 The SHO should seek clinical advice from the Middle Grade doctor who is on call or from the Consultant if they are concerned about the patient's condition or if they require advice regarding diagnosis or treatment of the patient's condition. The Middle Grade doctor and Consultant on call will be contacted by telephone.

4.4.5 The A&E doctor or the ENT doctor on call (any of the grades) may decide that it is not appropriate for the patient to be transferred to ward E322 for an ENT review. If this is the case, the SHO should ask the Middle Grade doctor to attend the relevant A&E department to review the patient. If the Middle Grade doctor has been called to another unit to review a patient, the Consultant on call should be contacted by telephone and asked to attend the relevant A&E department to provide an ENT review for the patient.

4.4.6 Following an ENT review in A&E by the Middle Grade doctor or Consultant on call if the decision is made to admit the patient they will only be transferred to the Hub ward for admission if they are in a stable condition and safe to transfer. If it is not considered safe to transfer the patient or they require admission for ITU for example for patients with airway problems, the patient will be kept at the Spoke hospital. The patient will be admitted to a ward or ITU at the Spoke hospital and treated there until the patient's condition has stabilised and it is safe to transfer them to the Hub. If further ENT opinion or review is required at the Spoke for these patients out of hours the Middle Grade doctor or Consultant on call will provide this.
4.4.7 The SHO must notify the ward nursing staff of any emergency patient who is expected from A&E including which A&E department the patient is coming from.

4.4.8 The A&E department should notify the relevant ward (E322 for adults and E122 for children) when the patient has left their department for transfer to the Hub and provide an estimated arrival time for the patient where possible.
4.4.9 If the patient is a child the SHO must request that the child attends Moonbeam ward (E122) and the SHO must notify Moonbeam ward nursing staff of the expected emergency patient.
4.4.10 The patient will be transferred by ambulance if clinically indicated or if appropriate via their own transport.
When the patient arrives on the ward – Mayflower Ward (E322) for adults and Moonbeam Ward (E122) for children, the nursing staff should greet the patient and show them where to wait.
The patient will be shown into the treatment room, the waiting room or to a bed depending on the patient's condition and if the doctor is free and ready to see the patient.

The patient will have a baseline set of observations taken and these will be recorded on the ward attender form. (See Appendix 1: Ward Attender Form). The patient will be seen and examined by the SHO within 30 minutes of arrival or sooner, dependent upon clinical need, who will then  decide the clinical management of the patient's condition.
The SHO will seek clinical advice from the Middle Grade doctor who is on call or from the Consultant on call as required. The Middle Grade or Consultant on call will be contacted by telephone.

The SHO will ask the Middle Grade doctor to come in and review the patient as required. If the Middle Grade doctor has been called to another unit to review a patient, the Consultant on call will provide this review.

For children the initial examination and diagnosis will be undertaken in the treatment room on Moonbeam (E122) ward. If the child requires examination using the microscope the doctor will contact ward E322 and advise them that he/she is bringing a child up for examination in the treatment room.

The doctor and a nurse from Moonbeam ward will escort the child and his/her parents/guardians up to the treatment room. As soon as the examination is complete, the child and his/her parents/guardians will be escorted back to Moonbeam ward for further management or discharge.
All patients should have a ward attender outcome form completed by the SHO on call who sees the patient. A member of the nursing staff out of hours will fax
a copy of this form to the Spoke clinic or ward if a patient requires a follow up appointment.

The ward clerk will be responsible for entering the ward attender information and outcomes onto Lorenzo on the computer each day Monday to Friday. Patients who are seen over the week-end should be entered onto Lorenzo on the following Monday by the ward clerk.
When a diagnosis and treatment plan has been established the patient will have one of the following outcomes.
See and Treat

6.2.1 The patient is given the required treatment room on the ward E322 for adults and Moonbeam ward (E122) for children. Advice and any required medication to take home will be given to the patient with instructions and the patient is discharged home.

6.2.2 If a patient attended the ward for review by ambulance and can be discharged home the ward staff, where possible, should investigate alternative methods of transport home with the patient, for example patient's relatives or friends. If the patient requires hospital transport home the transport policy should be followed (See Appendix 2: Transport policy).

6.2.3 If a follow up appointment is needed the patient will be advised of any follow up appointments that may be required either back on the Hub ward or in the ENT clinic or ward at their Spoke hospital. They will be told where and when to attend for their follow up appointment before they are discharged.

6.2.4 As it is out of hours a method of allocating appointment times must be agreed with the Spoke hospitals, for example the Hub ward will have access to appointment slots in each Spoke clinic or ward that patients can be booked into. The patient should be notified of the time and location to attend for their follow up appointment. A copy of the ward attender form would then be faxed to the relevant department at the Spoke hospital (numbers to be confirmed) to notify them of who would be attending for an appointment and notification of the treatment given at the Hub).
Admission

6.3.1 The SHO can make the decision to admit a patient for treatment on their own or following advice from the Middle Grade doctor or Consultant on call. The SHO will notify the nursing staff on ward E322 for an adult patient and Moonbeam ward (E122) for a child that a patient requires admission. The bed manager/service co-ordinator will be contacted and notified of the admission by the doctor. If no bed is available on ward E322 a bed will have to be found by the bed manager/service co-ordinator on the Broomfield hospital site and the patient will be repatriated to ward E322 as soon as a bed becomes available. If a bed is not available on Moonbeam ward the SHO should contact the Consultant on call for further advice on the management of the child. They should then liaise with Moonbeam ward and the bed manager/ service co- ordinator.

6.3.2 Once the decision to admit is made the patient will have a documented treatment plan written down by the doctor in a temporary set of medical notes and the patient will receive a full nursing assessment.
Emergency Surgery

6.4.1  If it is decided that the patient needs to go to theatre this will be arranged with the anaesthetic service and performed by the middle grade/Consultant dependent upon the needs of the patient.
Post Operative Care
6.5.1 The service has 24 hour Junior Doctor ward cover at the Hub, with off site on- call cover from the spokes at Middle Grade and Consultant level out of hours.

6.5.2 In addition to the above it is agreed that daily ward rounds will be conducted by a Consultant and further support can be provided from Consultants who are operating in theatres located opposite E322 or MEHT Consultants based at the adjacent spoke at St. Johns.

Palliative care patients who require ENT care will only be transferred to the Hub in exceptional circumstances. Where possible the patient will be treated in accordance to their preferred place of care.
If a Head and Neck palliative care patient is admitted to ward E322 the patient should be referred to the Mid Essex hospital Macmillan team by the next working day (Monday to Friday).
The Head and Neck cancer nurse specialist for the patient's locality should also be notified of the patient's admission on b y the next working day.
Head and Neck clinical nurse specialists:
Southend and Basildon patients telephone #6165 ext 6286 or via mobile 07659 181 073
Colchester patients telephone 01206 744 783 or via mobile 07659 509 413
Mid Essex patients contact via ward E322 or telephone 01245 513 114 and leave a message or via pager number #6400 252.
Approval and Implementation

This policy will be reviewed and agreed by the Elective Care Group. This document will be approved by Document Ratification Group and available electronically on the Trust intranet site and staff will be informed of any updates.
